thread.title: WestJet and Disney reveal new Frozen themed plane
thread.title_full: WestJet and Disney reveal new Frozen themed plane

title: WestJet and Disney reveal new Frozen themed plane
text:
WestJet and Disney reveal new Frozen themed plane Last updated 10:29, October 19 2015 West Jet 
Disney's Frozen-themed plane unveiled 
Elsa, Anna and Olaf have been taken to heady new heights after WestJet revealed their new Frozen themed plane. 
According to World Airline News , the stunning livery - a project brought to life by WestJet, WestJet Vacations and The Walt Disney Company (Canada) - is a "celebration of sisterhood" shared between Anna and Elsa, who are featured on the tail of the plane. 
The livery also showcases the "magic of snow" before moving onto warmer climates down the side of the aircraft, where lovable snowman Olaf can be seen sunning himself on the beach. A photo posted by @westjet on Oct 18, 2015 at 9:12am PDT 
The Frozen theme also continues into the plane, with overhead bins, bulkheads, toilet mirrors and headrests all receiving a Frozen makeover. 
This is the second time WestJet have created a bit of magic in flight. Two years ago the company launched their #magicplane which featured Mickey Mouse. WestJet/Instagram 
"westjet#Elsa, with her magical snow powers, graces the tail of our newest custom-painted aircraft." 
"This aircraft takes the relationship between WestJet and Disney to a completely new level of cool," Bob Cummings, WestJet Executive Vice-President, Commercial said. 
"Two years ago, we launched the #MagicPlane, our first Disney-themed aircraft, and no matter where it flies throughout our network, it is the most-anticipated and most-photographed aircraft in WestJet history. Today, we are proud to team up with our great friends at Disney to create a sequel like no other." 
According to World Airline News, the plane was painted by team members from Canada, the US and Germany, who were said to have watched Frozen to "get them into the spirit" before work began. 
The job took 21, 24 hour days to complete. Sparkles were added to the paint in certain sections to allow the aircraft to "shimmer and shine" as it moves.
